item.title: Physically Based Rendering In OpenGL Using GLTF2
item.description:
In this video we learn how to modernize our OpenGL rendering pipeline using a physically based rendering technique based on the GLTF2 format.
üî•For more information: üîπLoad models using Assimp: https://youtu.be/sP_kiODC25Q üîπPaper by Carmelo J. Fdez-Aguera: https://www.jcgt.org/published/0008/01/03/paper.pdf üîπArticle by Bruno Opsenica: https://bruop.github.io/ibl/ üîπVulkan 3D Graphics Rendering Cookbook 2nd ed (affiliate link): https://amzn.to/3T7rK6V
üî• See the list of the books that I'm using as background information for my tutorials: https://ogldev.org/books.html. I highly recommend them for learning more about OpenGL and Vulkan. These are affiliate links so if you use them to buy any of the books the price is the same for you and I will get a small commission (thank-you!).
üìö Timecodes üìö 0:00 Intro and background 0:44 GLTF2 2:04 Metallic Roughness workflow 3:06 Assimp support for PBR 3:59 More textures 5:58 Vertex Shader 6:14 Fragment Shader 6:56 High level view 8:05 Prep some stuff 10:41 Schlick approximation 11:33 Precomputed BRDF table 13:57 Specular color 17:20 Diffuse color 18:07 Irradiance map 21:31 Single directional light 24:58 Outro
Please visit https://ogldev.org to see more of my tutorials on modern OpenGL.
üî•Link to source: https://github.com/emeiri/ogldev.git If you want to get the same version of the code that was used in the video checkout the tag 'TUT_64_PBR_GLTF2'
Feel free to comment below.
üîóContacts: üîπEmail: ogldev1@gmail.com üîπInstagram: @ogldev1 üîπGithub: https://github.com/emeiri/ogldev.git üîπTikTok - https://www.tiktok.com/@ogldev üîπTwitter: @ogldev üîπDiscord: https://discord.gg/CZdVwZgTYk üîπOne time donations (Paypal): https://ogldev.org/donate.html üîπPatreon: https://www.patreon.com/ogldev
üôèCredits: üîπMusic by Karl Casey @ White Bat Audio üîπOpenGL¬Æ is a registered trademark of Silicon Graphics International Corp. and is used under license by the Khronos Group üîπGLTF is a trademark of the Khronos Group üîπ"A Multiple-Scaterring Microfacet Model for Real-Time Image-Based lighting" by Carmelo J. Fdez-Aguera: https://www.jcgt.org/published/0008/01/03/paper.pdf üîπ"Image Based Lighting with Multiple Scattering" by Bruno opstica: https://bruop.github.io/ibl/ üîπVideo by Olena and Adis Resic from https://Pixabay.com
Enjoy,
Etay Meiri

item.title: Qbix Streams as a Graph Database - Qbix Platform / Streams plugin - Qbix Community
item.description: Qbix Streams: A Searchable, Distributed Graph Database Hiding in Plain Sight When most people think of graph databases, they imagine Neo4j with its Cypher queries, or Firebase/Firestore for document search. These tools give you nodes, edges, and the ability to traverse relationships. But what if you could get all of that ‚Äî plus history, access control, federation, and SQL-speed search ‚Äî without leaving the comfort of relational databases? That‚Äôs exactly what the Qbix Streams architecture prov...

item.title: I Want a Cross-Platform Tiling Window Manager
item.description: One of the great things about building your own tools is that you get to have your desired workflow and user experience with very few compromises. I built Notado because I wanted an archiving and highlighting workflow which treated online comments as first class citizens. I built Kullish because I wanted to be able to quickly aggregate comments about links from a variety of different online communities. I built komorebi because I wanted a tiling window manager for Windows.

item.title: Exited Mac Development
item.description: I‚Äôm out # A few months ago I stopped selling my Mac applications (PopDo and FreelanceStation). I have more than enough reasons to not waste my time on continued support for them, which I‚Äôm going to discuss below. Lost my love for Mac software development # Many years have passed since I entered the Mac development market. I loved how Mac applications felt, and I still do to a certain point, even though I admired large complex applications, such as 3D multi-platform software, audio tools, digital painting or even engineering software.

item.title: Following processes won't make you a robot
item.description: Think of an SOP as a cooking recipe, albeit rather a Kenji L√≥pez-Alt recipe then a grocery store meal box one. It's an extensive overview of what we want to achieve, how we do it (step by step), what is involved (connections and roles) ,and what the end result should look like. Ideally there is also documentation and change logs, but those are a bit more rare.
